transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church needs to modernize some of its views. Lately, I've heard they're losing members, and I think it's because they aren't very accepting of certain things.  

Take things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong opinions on these issues, which is fine, but some of those views seem pretty outdated. If they loosened up a bit, maybe they wouldn't be worried about losing followers.

People are starting to disagree with the Church's stance on these topics.  They see it as a negative thing, like if you believe in abortion, you might not feel comfortable being part of a group that condemns it.  Same with gay marriage – if you support it, you might not want to be in a group that opposes it.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or why priests can't be married. I mean, everyone else gets to have a family and a job; why not priests?

I'm not against gay marriage.  I think that whether someone is born that way or not, it's not a choice they make.  So, I feel like gay people shouldn't be blamed for who they are attracted to. It doesn't seem fair to me that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't.  Honestly, I haven't thought about it too much, but I definitely think it's wrong to deny them that right.


I guess it's like this: I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay.  It doesn't feel like a choice either way. So, why should someone be held accountable for something they can't control? It just doesn't seem right to me.

I don't think the government should get involved in this. It's not a legal issue or really even a moral one.  I don't think gay people should be put on a pedestal or treated like they made a bad decision.  

The federal government shouldn't have a say in this. It doesn't affect national security or morals. It just seems like they're overstepping boundaries.  People should be able to live their lives as they choose, and that includes who they love. It's just who they are, and they shouldn't be punished for it.

I think gay marriage should be legal. There's really no good reason not to allow it.  Some people worry that gay couples threaten the traditional family, but that just doesn't make sense. It's like saying heads and tails are the same thing just because they're both sides of a coin. They're different, but both valid.  

There are lots of civil rights tied to marriage, too. For example, if you're in a gay couple, your partner might not be able to visit you in the hospital or make medical decisions for you if you're sick. It's kind of unfair if you're committed to someone for life.

Plus, research shows that gay couples have the same success rates and relationship dynamics as straight couples. It's just a relationship, plain and simple.  

What gets people hung up is the idea of churches and religion. But gay couples aren't asking to get married in a church; they're asking for a legal document from the government. If the government doesn't get involved in religious matters, it shouldn't be an issue.

It's like segregation – separate but unequal. Gay couples deserve the same rights and recognition as everyone else. Some people worry about adoption and how it will affect children, but studies haven't shown any negative impacts. The biggest problem kids of same-sex couples face is bullying and prejudice from others.

I think the federal government should definitely make gay marriage legal nationwide. It's a matter of equality and basic human rights. President Bush, however, seems to have strong religious beliefs that influence his stance on gay marriage, which aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. 

His reasoning often comes down to morality, but morality is subjective and varies widely. It's not fair to impose the religious beliefs of one group on the entire country. Plus, it's hypocritical to oppose "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance while supporting laws based on religious beliefs.

Some people believe being gay is a psychological defect or a result of childhood trauma.  But that's simply not true, according to the American Psychological Association. We need to base our views on facts and research, not on prejudice and misinformation.

So, I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and it's made me think a lot about drugs.  I mean, just because something is illegal doesn't automatically mean it's bad.  Take marijuana, for example.  I think it should be legal for medicinal purposes because its potential benefits shouldn't be ignored just because of its legal status.  It's not like it's heroin or cocaine.

Think about it, pharmacies use lots of controlled substances like oxycontin, Vicodin, and Percocet all the time. They're helpful, right?  But there's this stigma around marijuana that makes people forget it could have similar benefits.

Alcohol is different, though.  Both alcohol and marijuana can be abused, but I think we should focus on removing the taboo around marijuana first.  Maybe then people would use it more responsibly.

Honestly, the way people view marijuana is totally unfair.  It's not nearly as dangerous as other drugs, so if we changed people's perceptions, they might use it responsibly, especially for medical reasons.

I think the church has changed and adapted to be more modern. It's not as strict as it used to be.  When I was younger, I went to church every Sunday dressed up in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. That was the norm back then. I went to a private school and saw all my friends there every weekend.

Now, things are different. They have a special mass for teenagers that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially in the summer. You'll see families rushing in from the beach straight to church. Even at the morning masses, people wear jeans and khakis instead of the formal attire I wore before. It's definitely more relaxed.  That's the biggest change I've noticed.


As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I don't think allowing women priests or permitting priests to marry would have stopped those horrible acts.  There are married men who become pedophiles. It's not about being married or not. It's about the person themselves.  

If someone truly wants to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should consider a different religion, like some of the ones where ministers or reverends are allowed to marry. 

I think pedophilia has roots in genetics. It's something people are born with, not something they become.  You can't hide it through marriage. It might come out eventually. The church may have failed to address the issue properly in some cases, but I don't believe they could have prevented it altogether.

Man, you know, at first I was cool with the idea of the Iraq War, but everyone was still super shook up from 9/11. It felt like we rushed into it, using it as an excuse.  I mean, the Bush administration kept saying Saddam Hussein was connected to Bin Laden and had weapons of mass destruction, and we all know that turned out to be a big fat lie. That really rubbed me the wrong way. The whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil.

It feels like the Bush team straight-up lied to the American people, and they still haven't admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that huge speech at the UN, now says he wasn't totally convinced by the evidence back then, even while he was presenting it! To me, that's just wrong, plain and simple. It's like, how can you lie to the country like that? That's gotta be grounds for impeachment! And it's not just that; it feels like the Bush administration has been trying to push the Constitution aside ever since 9/11.

It seems like they came into office wanting to go to war. I can't remember the name of the Treasury Secretary who said this, but he wrote about it in his book after he got pushed out. It sounds like the younger Bush had some personal beef with Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration, and maybe he also wanted to control Iraq's oil. It's all pretty sneaky if you ask me.

I think it's gone on long enough, though. If we pulled out right now, things could get really messy and even more people could die. It seems like the UN and the US are trying to get countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help set things right. But I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It could cause more problems in the long run because it messes with Iraq's sovereignty. 

The government is falling apart. The news says the Parliament isn't doing much, and the Prime Minister doesn't really seem to be in charge. Even that guy, Mugtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not too long ago, his party now has seats in Parliament!  We're still dealing with all these different groups fighting for control, and it's creating a lot of chaos.

I'm not sure how to put this into words.  It feels like a pointless war, you know? I mean, it wasn't even officially declared. It just feels like we invaded Iraq because we thought they were behind 9/11.  Honestly, I don't really follow the news about it closely. I don't know all the details.

But, from what I gather, we're still there trying to build democracy and get access to their oil.  The problem is, it's creating a lot of anger. Staying there forever to build a democracy will take ages, and if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing everything up.

It's a real dilemma.  It makes me wonder if we should even call it a war anymore. We never actually declared it. It seems like we're just showing off our military power and trying to make ourselves look big.

Part of me feels like we should stay and help them, but it's also costing us so much, and it's making President Bush look bad. I worry he'll become known as the president who started another pointless war, just like Vietnam.

Then there are the families with loved ones in Iraq. I hate to say it, but I want the war to end for them, but I also don't want us to just abandon the people of Iraq. They've lost so much.

I feel like if we stay, we'll try to make them more like us, which could backfire. It might make things worse and fuel more hatred towards America. 

This whole situation feels like it's going to drag on forever. Ugh, it's just so complicated.

You know, I don't think it's right for the government to make this legal or for any state to even try to say it's okay.  It just seems like something the churches should decide for themselves. The Constitution clearly states the separation of church and state, and it seems to me that trying to control or influence this issue goes against what's already been established.

I think people pushing to make it illegal are basically picking one church's beliefs over another.  As we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except maybe in some areas like Boston. But it shouldn't be up to the government to decide what churches can or can't do.

The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of the Constitution and something that allows for religious freedom in the United States. Even though there have been talks about making an amendment,  I think adding one about this would be completely wrong and go against what's already written. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that's actually used to restrict people instead of the government, which doesn't seem right.

I firmly believe the federal government, or any government for that matter, shouldn't be involved in this. I don't understand why someone would push for this amendment unless it's based on their own personal beliefs as a Catholic. It seems like they're just trying to favor one religion over all others.  It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government official. There isn't really a good reason to support this amendment, other than personal views. I don't see how it would affect the economy or anything else in a negative way. In fact, it might even have a positive impact on society.

Okay, so the war in Iraq... I really don't think the government was completely honest with us about why they wanted to go to war. Before invading, they tried to link it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really connected. They used our fear and anger from 9/11 to push for the invasion in 2003.  Personally, I'm against war in almost any situation, especially preemptive strikes.

This Iraq war feels a lot like Vietnam, and we should have learned from our mistakes there.  A huge number of American soldiers have died, and it's terrible.  

They went in and just removed the Iraqi government without really thinking about what would happen next. They didn't plan for the chaos, the power vacuum, and all the fallout. The US is trying to install a democracy, just like they did in Vietnam, but pushing out Communists and trying to force democracy on a country is never easy. It's a long and difficult process, and we should have known that going in.

It wasn't a clear-cut victory like they made it seem. It's more like a loss, because no matter how many people support you, there will always be insurgents. You can't defeat a whole population when you're not fighting a traditional army.

So, I think we shouldn't have gone to war in the first place. But if we were going to, we needed to be prepared for everything. We weren't ready for the aftermath, for what would happen once they took out Saddam Hussein.

We're still there in 2006, with American troops still dying, and we're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police. It's a long process.  

The government kind of misled the American people, making it seem like a short, successful mission. But implementing a new form of government takes years, and it's not easy. Just look at our own history! It took a long struggle to get to the strong democracy we have today.

So, what do we do now? It's a tough decision. We can't just abandon Iraq now after everything we've done. But how many more lives are we willing to lose for a free and democratic Iraq?

And let's be honest, why just Iraq? Why not other countries? I think the oil is a big factor. We need that oil, and it's often about controlling resources.

Remember, they also said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they never found any. But North Korea has those weapons, and we're not doing anything about it.  I don't think the US government is being truthful or thorough enough.


I just hope it ends soon and there's peace there, but I'm not very optimistic.

I'm a big supporter of gay marriage, always have been.  It's a personal choice, and research shows it could even be biological rather than social.  It just feels wrong to take away someone's rights based on something they can't control.  I think it's unfair and inhumane.  I've always been an advocate for equal rights for everyone, including gay couples.

I don't think politics or the government should have anything to do with it. It's a personal matter, something between two people and their families.  In my neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who aren't married because they can't be. They live their lives just like any other family, walking their dogs and being part of the community.  

It seems like President Bush is trying to play God by interpreting marriage in his own way. I think it's ridiculous.

I've read and heard from lots of sources that being gay might be a biological thing, something you're predisposed to. It's not a choice you make based on your upbringing or environment.  

Besides the obvious, I think it's unfair that a couple can just run off and get married without anyone knowing, but if two gay people want to do the same thing, it's a huge deal. It should be a private matter, something between the couple and their family, not something that's splashed all over the news.  It shouldn't be a national issue.

So, basically, when you put something on the internet, it's out there for everyone to see.  It's like a public space. As an RA, I've dealt with this before.  Once you post something online, it shapes how people perceive you. If you're talking about causing harm, like explosions or shootings, someone's going to take notice. You can't just put that out there for the world to see. The internet reaches everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll see their posts.  

It doesn't matter if it's the school that got the alert, someone saw it and reported it. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have stopped it.

But then again, it's hard to know what's serious and what's just people messing around. Maybe it was a social experiment that went wrong, like for a sociology class. 

Or maybe it was something really serious. In this case, something happened at school, someone overheard a conversation, and they reported it. When they looked through the person's Facebook, they found things that were concerning, even if the person meant them as a joke. In the end, the internet doesn't offer much privacy. If you don't want people to see something, don't post it. You can't control how people interpret it.

It's not okay for school officials to be friends with their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if someone brings something to their attention, it's not really an invasion of privacy because the person shared it with others. If there's a potential danger, they have to take it seriously.

I think schools should focus on what's brought to their attention directly, not on monitoring phone calls, texts, or IMs.

I feel like this war has dragged on far too long. At the start, the goal seemed good—to bring democracy to a country lacking a fair political system. But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that original purpose. Now, it feels like we're fighting just to prove our power, not for any real reason.  

Plus, I wonder if the motives were ever truly pure. There were definitely connections to personal grudges between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was to help establish democracy, that would be a noble cause. But if personal matters were involved, then it's not right.

Regardless, the war has gone on way too long. We made our point in the beginning, but hanging on for years just isn't necessary. Their government and people need to figure things out on their own.

It's draining our economy. We're spending billions on a war that seems to have lost its purpose, while neglecting our own problems like poverty, failing infrastructure, and inadequate healthcare. That money could be better used to help our own citizens.  

It's just not right to keep pouring resources into a war that seems endless. We need to bring our troops home and focus on solving the issues we have right here at home.

So, someone was asking if it was okay for someone to look at people's Myspace profiles to prevent something bad from happening.  I think it's pretty much fair game if you post something online, especially on a site like Myspace where you have to be friends with someone to see their profile. If you're friends with someone, you're giving them permission to see what you post.  

It's tough though, because you can't have someone constantly checking everyone's profiles. It would be like singling out certain kids as "bad" and targeting them. It's a tricky situation. Maybe it depends on the situation. If someone sees something specific that raises a red flag, then it might be justified. 

I personally have a Facebook, and it's unsettling knowing that anyone could see my information. I once saw a news story about a guy who easily found someone's information from their profile and started chatting with them. It's scary how much information is out there.  

I try to be careful about what I share online, but it's hard because I want to connect with my friends. It's a balancing act. 

I also heard that some high schools actually banned Myspace.  It seems strange to me that schools would have that kind of control over what their students do online.  It feels like a privacy issue.

I feel awkward talking about the Iraq War, you know? It's hard not to feel like I'm jumping on the bandwagon of people who were against it from the start.  But honestly, looking back, it's clear to me that it was a mistake.  Everyone seems to agree, except maybe for the people in the government who don't want to admit they were wrong.  There have been polls everywhere – in the U.S., Iraq, and globally – showing that 75 to 80% of people think the war was a bad idea.  Even a lot of the U.S. troops stationed there believe we should get out within the next year.

It feels like everything about the war has been a disaster, even before we even went in.  Pulling out is going to be a mess too, and there's no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East.  It's a clash of cultures, and it seems like our government just doesn't understand that. They think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't fit. 

Sure, Saddam Hussein was a bad guy, but invading a country should never be taken lightly.  You have to weigh the pros and cons carefully, and in this case, the cons far outweigh the pros.  It's like quicksand – once we went in, we got stuck.

I don't know what to say about it anymore. I don't see any reason for us to stay there. The administration probably has some hopeful ideas about why we should stay, and maybe there are some risks involved in leaving. But I haven't heard any convincing reasons why we shouldn't just go.

If they wanted to pull out gradually over a year or so, I wouldn't have much of a problem with that. But the longer we stay, the worse it seems to get. I read that 80% of Iraqis want us to leave within the year, and a lot of them want us to leave right now. They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave. Maybe they know better than we do.

If we ask them what they want, and they say they want us to leave, then at least we can say we gave them a choice. If things go bad after that, we can say we tried to do what was best, but they ultimately made the decision.  Maybe then we could at least be seen as the good guys, or at least less bad.

Yeah, I totally think gender discrimination is still a thing in the U.S. It's not just about women though. It's more about the specific field you're working in.  I mean, overall, women face tougher times because of that invisible "glass ceiling."  Even though equality is the goal, many people struggle to work for a woman in a leadership position, just because of how society's always been. So, often, women see a job they're qualified for, but the board might not promote them because traditionally, women haven't held top positions in business. And, I guess the same goes for men too.  

Think about things like being a stay-at-home parent. It's super uncommon for a man to stay home while his wife works. People often judge them, assuming the man should be the breadwinner. It can be tough for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be at home with their kids, even if their wife has the higher-paying job.  But society doesn't get it.

And then there's the fashion industry.  Men who are into fashion, especially straight men, sometimes don't get taken seriously. I don't know if that makes sense, but maybe it's because people think guys who are into fashion have different lifestyles. So, if a guy fits the typical mold and he's in fashion, people might wonder, "How can he really understand fashion if he's not more like us, the women?"

It's like, depending on your field, there's definitely gender discrimination in the U.S. Changing it is tough because society has a set way of thinking, even though we've come a long way since the 1800s. Change is slow, but women are rising in business, becoming CEOs and getting more acceptance.  It's happening, and people are starting to get on board.

The same goes for stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because people realize maybe the wife is the better earner, or maybe she just wants to work. And in fashion, maybe people are listening to their wives or female friends and understanding where men are coming from.

So, we have to promote these stereotypes by showing off the good qualities of those who are usually looked down on, but not in a pushy way. You can't force change, or people will resist. We're in a good spot where things are starting to change naturally.  

I don't think there's anything else we can do right now besides what's already being done. Change takes time, and we've already come a long way.  

Oh, and I think people discriminate against each other based on where they're from too. If a guy grew up on a farm and his grammar isn't perfect, but he's super smart and becomes a CEO, some men might make fun of him, saying things like, "How can I trust you if you don't even speak correctly?" You know?

So, they didn't exactly make marijuana legal, they decriminalized it.  

Think of it like this: instead of being a criminal offense, it's now more like a traffic ticket.  You get cited, but you don't get arrested, booked, or hauled into jail. 

There are still some downsides though.  Even with decriminalization, things like job interviews might still be affected.  Those big, scary consequences of a drug charge, they don't always disappear.

But, on the other hand, getting caught with marijuana used to cost taxpayers a ton of money.  Think about it: arresting people, holding them in jail, court appearances, public defenders, judges, prosecutors... it all adds up. 

Places that are struggling financially might be hesitant to decriminalize even if it saved them money. 

Some places, like Denver, are more open to the idea.  They might even use the money saved to fund things like education, social programs, and food assistance.  

It's important to remember that just because something is decriminalized doesn't mean it should be everywhere.  We need to be careful about how it's handled.

If marijuana were fully legalized, it could end up like cigarettes, sold in gas stations and smoked everywhere.  That could lead to more people smoking and driving, and it might just feel uncomfortable for a lot of people.

I think alcohol actually has a bigger impact on your ability to drive safely, but marijuana can be more disruptive to someone's everyday life.  

Ultimately, every substance affects people differently.  Some people can handle it better than others.  It's tough to generalize.

I'd say yes, because a lot of what they do is pretty traditional. They've done things the same way for ages, and it's good to have those roots. But it's also important to be able to change with the times, you know?  

A lot of Catholics think they have to go to church every week, and they're pretty strict about how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow every single rule perfectly.  They don't really accept people who aren't exactly "ideal" Catholics, and they don't accept people of other religions either.  Like, for example, my dad was an Episcopalian and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't let them get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion.

It doesn't seem very tolerant of other faiths to me. We were always taught to love everyone, which is a Catholic thing, but it feels hypocritical to say you love others and then not accept them the way they are.  So, a lot of Catholic teachings are about doing things a certain way, but then the way they actually practice goes against it because it's so stuck in the past.

I don't think allowing priests to get married would necessarily change things. I personally think it would be a good idea, but I don't think it would stop priests from abusing children. It's a whole different issue.  It might help a little, but I'm not sure.


I mean, people who hurt children probably would do it whether or not they were married. It's about a power imbalance, not about being married or not. If someone is going to abuse a child, they're going to do it whether they have a spouse or not. I don't think letting priests get married would stop that from happening.

I'm still figuring out my stance on this whole marriage equality debate. It's really tough, you know? It feels like it walks a fine line between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage actually means.  It's hard not to offend anyone when you're trying to define something so personal. 

I'm leaning towards the idea that all unions, whether they're between two men, two women, or a man and a woman, should be treated as civil unions.  After all, the government doesn't get involved in religious ceremonies like baptism, right?  Why should marriage be any different?  It's about two people coming together, and that's what matters.

I think it's important for the government to stay out of people's personal lives and not dictate who they can marry.  If all the states can agree on a reasonable solution, maybe they could push for it to become federal law.  

But a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? That seems extreme.  Changing the constitution shouldn't be taken lightly, especially for something like this. It's a big deal for some people, but I don't think it's important enough to warrant amending the constitution.

Growing up in a Christian household, my views on homosexuality are a bit complicated. I have lots of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I believe they should have the right to marry. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something decided by each individual state.

Think about it: some states are more liberal, while others are more conservative. Democratic states are more likely to support gay marriage, and people living there should be able to live in accordance with their state's values. If you choose to live in a state that legalizes it, you're essentially accepting that decision.

Basically, I think everyone, regardless of sexual orientation, deserves equal opportunities. So, I believe in leaving the decision of whether or not to legalize gay marriage up to each state. 

I don't think President Bush should have the power to ban it nationwide.  He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't be able to dictate how each state should govern itself. Plus, with a new president potentially coming in soon, it's likely to become a back-and-forth issue. It's best to let individual states make their own choices, as they're the ones who will ultimately live with the consequences.

Look, I get it. Myspace is like a public bulletin board, right? Whatever you post, anyone can see it. So if you're putting something on there, you kind of have to assume people are going to see it, even people like school officials. I mean, even if they weren't looking under the school's name, they could still find it from home. 

But when it comes to preventing something terrible like a school shooting, I think the school has a responsibility to keep everyone safe. If they see something online that makes them think a student might be a danger, I think it's okay for them to look into it. 

It's different if they're just snooping around looking for kids doing things they shouldn't, like drinking or smoking. That's an invasion of privacy. But if it's about protecting kids, I think it's fine. 

Think about it: you wouldn't want to send your kid to a school where the staff wasn't doing everything they could to keep them safe, right? 

It's just like with emails. You wouldn't want to put anything nasty about someone in an email because you never know who might see it later.  Everything online can come back to bite you. 

So, yeah, I think the school officials were justified in looking at the Myspace page. They were just trying to keep everyone safe.

Okay, so, about the war... at first, I was all for it because 9/11 hit me personally. I wanted revenge, you know? But looking back, I think we went in too emotionally.  We didn't really plan things out, and now I think it backfired.

I don't think being there is helping. It seems like they're just fighting amongst themselves anyway, and we're caught in the middle.  Honestly, because of 9/11, I've kind of checked out. I don't care what happens over there anymore.

It's frustrating. They're so different from us when it comes to war. It's savage. They don't want to make their country better; they just want us out. And maybe that's okay. Maybe we should just leave.

I think we were more angry than anything when we went in.  We wanted revenge, and I think President Bush let that dictate his actions.  But I get it, we couldn't just ignore what happened.

I just wish we had a better plan. We didn't know what we were walking into, and I don't think we had a clear goal. There wasn't any unity. 

We made some progress, but it's not enough.  We can't stay forever, and I honestly think things will just fall apart once we leave. We're hurting ourselves by staying there.

transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church needs to modernize some of its views. Lately, I've heard they're losing members, and I think it's because they aren't very accepting of certain things.  

Take things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong opinions on these issues, which is fine, but some of those views seem pretty outdated. If they loosened up a bit, maybe they wouldn't be worried about losing followers.

People are starting to disagree with the Church's stance on these topics.  They see it as a negative thing, like if you believe in abortion, you might not feel comfortable being part of a group that condemns it.  Same with gay marriage – if you support it, you might not want to be in a group that opposes it.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or why priests can't be married. I mean, everyone else gets to have a family and a job; why not priests?

I'm not against gay marriage.  I think that whether someone is born that way or not, it's not a choice they make.  So, I feel like gay people shouldn't be blamed for who they are attracted to. It doesn't seem fair to me that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't.  Honestly, I haven't thought about it too much, but I definitely think it's wrong to deny them that right.


I guess it's like this: I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay.  It doesn't feel like a choice either way. So, why should someone be held accountable for something they can't control? It just doesn't seem right to me.

I don't think the government should get involved in this. It's not a legal issue or really even a moral one.  I don't think gay people should be put on a pedestal or treated like they made a bad decision.  

The federal government shouldn't have a say in this. It doesn't affect national security or morals. It just seems like they're overstepping boundaries.  People should be able to live their lives as they choose, and that includes who they love. It's just who they are, and they shouldn't be punished for it.

I think gay marriage should be legal. There's really no good reason not to allow it.  Some people worry that gay couples threaten the traditional family, but that just doesn't make sense. It's like saying heads and tails are the same thing just because they're both sides of a coin. They're different, but both valid.  

There are lots of civil rights tied to marriage, too. For example, if you're in a gay couple, your partner might not be able to visit you in the hospital or make medical decisions for you if you're sick. It's kind of unfair if you're committed to someone for life.

Plus, research shows that gay couples have the same success rates and relationship dynamics as straight couples. It's just a relationship, plain and simple.  

What gets people hung up is the idea of churches and religion. But gay couples aren't asking to get married in a church; they're asking for a legal document from the government. If the government doesn't get involved in religious matters, it shouldn't be an issue.

It's like segregation – separate but unequal. Gay couples deserve the same rights and recognition as everyone else. Some people worry about adoption and how it will affect children, but studies haven't shown any negative impacts. The biggest problem kids of same-sex couples face is bullying and prejudice from others.

I think the federal government should definitely make gay marriage legal nationwide. It's a matter of equality and basic human rights. President Bush, however, seems to have strong religious beliefs that influence his stance on gay marriage, which aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. 

His reasoning often comes down to morality, but morality is subjective and varies widely. It's not fair to impose the religious beliefs of one group on the entire country. Plus, it's hypocritical to oppose "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance while supporting laws based on religious beliefs.

Some people believe being gay is a psychological defect or a result of childhood trauma.  But that's simply not true, according to the American Psychological Association. We need to base our views on facts and research, not on prejudice and misinformation.

So, I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and it's made me think a lot about drugs.  I mean, just because something is illegal doesn't automatically mean it's bad.  Take marijuana, for example.  I think it should be legal for medicinal purposes because its potential benefits shouldn't be ignored just because of its legal status.  It's not like it's heroin or cocaine.

Think about it, pharmacies use lots of controlled substances like oxycontin, Vicodin, and Percocet all the time. They're helpful, right?  But there's this stigma around marijuana that makes people forget it could have similar benefits.

Alcohol is different, though.  Both alcohol and marijuana can be abused, but I think we should focus on removing the taboo around marijuana first.  Maybe then people would use it more responsibly.

Honestly, the way people view marijuana is totally unfair.  It's not nearly as dangerous as other drugs, so if we changed people's perceptions, they might use it responsibly, especially for medical reasons.

I think the church has changed and adapted to be more modern. It's not as strict as it used to be.  When I was younger, I went to church every Sunday dressed up in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. That was the norm back then. I went to a private school and saw all my friends there every weekend.

Now, things are different. They have a special mass for teenagers that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially in the summer. You'll see families rushing in from the beach straight to church. Even at the morning masses, people wear jeans and khakis instead of the formal attire I wore before. It's definitely more relaxed.  That's the biggest change I've noticed.


As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I don't think allowing women priests or permitting priests to marry would have stopped those horrible acts.  There are married men who become pedophiles. It's not about being married or not. It's about the person themselves.  

If someone truly wants to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should consider a different religion, like some of the ones where ministers or reverends are allowed to marry. 

I think pedophilia has roots in genetics. It's something people are born with, not something they become.  You can't hide it through marriage. It might come out eventually. The church may have failed to address the issue properly in some cases, but I don't believe they could have prevented it altogether.

Man, you know, at first I was cool with the idea of the Iraq War, but everyone was still super shook up from 9/11. It felt like we rushed into it, using it as an excuse.  I mean, the Bush administration kept saying Saddam Hussein was connected to Bin Laden and had weapons of mass destruction, and we all know that turned out to be a big fat lie. That really rubbed me the wrong way. The whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil.

It feels like the Bush team straight-up lied to the American people, and they still haven't admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that huge speech at the UN, now says he wasn't totally convinced by the evidence back then, even while he was presenting it! To me, that's just wrong, plain and simple. It's like, how can you lie to the country like that? That's gotta be grounds for impeachment! And it's not just that; it feels like the Bush administration has been trying to push the Constitution aside ever since 9/11.

It seems like they came into office wanting to go to war. I can't remember the name of the Treasury Secretary who said this, but he wrote about it in his book after he got pushed out. It sounds like the younger Bush had some personal beef with Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration, and maybe he also wanted to control Iraq's oil. It's all pretty sneaky if you ask me.

I think it's gone on long enough, though. If we pulled out right now, things could get really messy and even more people could die. It seems like the UN and the US are trying to get countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help set things right. But I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It could cause more problems in the long run because it messes with Iraq's sovereignty. 

The government is falling apart. The news says the Parliament isn't doing much, and the Prime Minister doesn't really seem to be in charge. Even that guy, Mugtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not too long ago, his party now has seats in Parliament!  We're still dealing with all these different groups fighting for control, and it's creating a lot of chaos.

I'm not sure how to put this into words.  It feels like a pointless war, you know? I mean, it wasn't even officially declared. It just feels like we invaded Iraq because we thought they were behind 9/11.  Honestly, I don't really follow the news about it closely. I don't know all the details.

But, from what I gather, we're still there trying to build democracy and get access to their oil.  The problem is, it's creating a lot of anger. Staying there forever to build a democracy will take ages, and if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing everything up.

It's a real dilemma.  It makes me wonder if we should even call it a war anymore. We never actually declared it. It seems like we're just showing off our military power and trying to make ourselves look big.

Part of me feels like we should stay and help them, but it's also costing us so much, and it's making President Bush look bad. I worry he'll become known as the president who started another pointless war, just like Vietnam.

Then there are the families with loved ones in Iraq. I hate to say it, but I want the war to end for them, but I also don't want us to just abandon the people of Iraq. They've lost so much.

I feel like if we stay, we'll try to make them more like us, which could backfire. It might make things worse and fuel more hatred towards America. 

This whole situation feels like it's going to drag on forever. Ugh, it's just so complicated.

You know, I don't think it's right for the government to make this legal or for any state to even try to say it's okay.  It just seems like something the churches should decide for themselves. The Constitution clearly states the separation of church and state, and it seems to me that trying to control or influence this issue goes against what's already been established.

I think people pushing to make it illegal are basically picking one church's beliefs over another.  As we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except maybe in some areas like Boston. But it shouldn't be up to the government to decide what churches can or can't do.

The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of the Constitution and something that allows for religious freedom in the United States. Even though there have been talks about making an amendment,  I think adding one about this would be completely wrong and go against what's already written. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that's actually used to restrict people instead of the government, which doesn't seem right.

I firmly believe the federal government, or any government for that matter, shouldn't be involved in this. I don't understand why someone would push for this amendment unless it's based on their own personal beliefs as a Catholic. It seems like they're just trying to favor one religion over all others.  It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government official. There isn't really a good reason to support this amendment, other than personal views. I don't see how it would affect the economy or anything else in a negative way. In fact, it might even have a positive impact on society.

Okay, so the war in Iraq... I really don't think the government was completely honest with us about why they wanted to go to war. Before invading, they tried to link it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really connected. They used our fear and anger from 9/11 to push for the invasion in 2003.  Personally, I'm against war in almost any situation, especially preemptive strikes.

This Iraq war feels a lot like Vietnam, and we should have learned from our mistakes there.  A huge number of American soldiers have died, and it's terrible.  

They went in and just removed the Iraqi government without really thinking about what would happen next. They didn't plan for the chaos, the power vacuum, and all the fallout. The US is trying to install a democracy, just like they did in Vietnam, but pushing out Communists and trying to force democracy on a country is never easy. It's a long and difficult process, and we should have known that going in.

It wasn't a clear-cut victory like they made it seem. It's more like a loss, because no matter how many people support you, there will always be insurgents. You can't defeat a whole population when you're not fighting a traditional army.

So, I think we shouldn't have gone to war in the first place. But if we were going to, we needed to be prepared for everything. We weren't ready for the aftermath, for what would happen once they took out Saddam Hussein.

We're still there in 2006, with American troops still dying, and we're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police. It's a long process.  

The government kind of misled the American people, making it seem like a short, successful mission. But implementing a new form of government takes years, and it's not easy. Just look at our own history! It took a long struggle to get to the strong democracy we have today.

So, what do we do now? It's a tough decision. We can't just abandon Iraq now after everything we've done. But how many more lives are we willing to lose for a free and democratic Iraq?

And let's be honest, why just Iraq? Why not other countries? I think the oil is a big factor. We need that oil, and it's often about controlling resources.

Remember, they also said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they never found any. But North Korea has those weapons, and we're not doing anything about it.  I don't think the US government is being truthful or thorough enough.


I just hope it ends soon and there's peace there, but I'm not very optimistic.

I'm a big supporter of gay marriage, always have been.  It's a personal choice, and research shows it could even be biological rather than social.  It just feels wrong to take away someone's rights based on something they can't control.  I think it's unfair and inhumane.  I've always been an advocate for equal rights for everyone, including gay couples.

I don't think politics or the government should have anything to do with it. It's a personal matter, something between two people and their families.  In my neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who aren't married because they can't be. They live their lives just like any other family, walking their dogs and being part of the community.  

It seems like President Bush is trying to play God by interpreting marriage in his own way. I think it's ridiculous.

I've read and heard from lots of sources that being gay might be a biological thing, something you're predisposed to. It's not a choice you make based on your upbringing or environment.  

Besides the obvious, I think it's unfair that a couple can just run off and get married without anyone knowing, but if two gay people want to do the same thing, it's a huge deal. It should be a private matter, something between the couple and their family, not something that's splashed all over the news.  It shouldn't be a national issue.

So, basically, when you put something on the internet, it's out there for everyone to see.  It's like a public space. As an RA, I've dealt with this before.  Once you post something online, it shapes how people perceive you. If you're talking about causing harm, like explosions or shootings, someone's going to take notice. You can't just put that out there for the world to see. The internet reaches everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll see their posts.  

It doesn't matter if it's the school that got the alert, someone saw it and reported it. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have stopped it.

But then again, it's hard to know what's serious and what's just people messing around. Maybe it was a social experiment that went wrong, like for a sociology class. 

Or maybe it was something really serious. In this case, something happened at school, someone overheard a conversation, and they reported it. When they looked through the person's Facebook, they found things that were concerning, even if the person meant them as a joke. In the end, the internet doesn't offer much privacy. If you don't want people to see something, don't post it. You can't control how people interpret it.

It's not okay for school officials to be friends with their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if someone brings something to their attention, it's not really an invasion of privacy because the person shared it with others. If there's a potential danger, they have to take it seriously.

I think schools should focus on what's brought to their attention directly, not on monitoring phone calls, texts, or IMs.

I feel like this war has dragged on far too long. At the start, the goal seemed good—to bring democracy to a country lacking a fair political system. But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that original purpose. Now, it feels like we're fighting just to prove our power, not for any real reason.  

Plus, I wonder if the motives were ever truly pure. There were definitely connections to personal grudges between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was to help establish democracy, that would be a noble cause. But if personal matters were involved, then it's not right.

Regardless, the war has gone on way too long. We made our point in the beginning, but hanging on for years just isn't necessary. Their government and people need to figure things out on their own.

It's draining our economy. We're spending billions on a war that seems to have lost its purpose, while neglecting our own problems like poverty, failing infrastructure, and inadequate healthcare. That money could be better used to help our own citizens.  

It's just not right to keep pouring resources into a war that seems endless. We need to bring our troops home and focus on solving the issues we have right here at home.

So, someone was asking if it was okay for someone to look at people's Myspace profiles to prevent something bad from happening.  I think it's pretty much fair game if you post something online, especially on a site like Myspace where you have to be friends with someone to see their profile. If you're friends with someone, you're giving them permission to see what you post.  

It's tough though, because you can't have someone constantly checking everyone's profiles. It would be like singling out certain kids as "bad" and targeting them. It's a tricky situation. Maybe it depends on the situation. If someone sees something specific that raises a red flag, then it might be justified. 

I personally have a Facebook, and it's unsettling knowing that anyone could see my information. I once saw a news story about a guy who easily found someone's information from their profile and started chatting with them. It's scary how much information is out there.  

I try to be careful about what I share online, but it's hard because I want to connect with my friends. It's a balancing act. 

I also heard that some high schools actually banned Myspace.  It seems strange to me that schools would have that kind of control over what their students do online.  It feels like a privacy issue.

I feel awkward talking about the Iraq War, you know? It's hard not to feel like I'm jumping on the bandwagon of people who were against it from the start.  But honestly, looking back, it's clear to me that it was a mistake.  Everyone seems to agree, except maybe for the people in the government who don't want to admit they were wrong.  There have been polls everywhere – in the U.S., Iraq, and globally – showing that 75 to 80% of people think the war was a bad idea.  Even a lot of the U.S. troops stationed there believe we should get out within the next year.

It feels like everything about the war has been a disaster, even before we even went in.  Pulling out is going to be a mess too, and there's no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East.  It's a clash of cultures, and it seems like our government just doesn't understand that. They think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't fit. 

Sure, Saddam Hussein was a bad guy, but invading a country should never be taken lightly.  You have to weigh the pros and cons carefully, and in this case, the cons far outweigh the pros.  It's like quicksand – once we went in, we got stuck.

I don't know what to say about it anymore. I don't see any reason for us to stay there. The administration probably has some hopeful ideas about why we should stay, and maybe there are some risks involved in leaving. But I haven't heard any convincing reasons why we shouldn't just go.

If they wanted to pull out gradually over a year or so, I wouldn't have much of a problem with that. But the longer we stay, the worse it seems to get. I read that 80% of Iraqis want us to leave within the year, and a lot of them want us to leave right now. They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave. Maybe they know better than we do.

If we ask them what they want, and they say they want us to leave, then at least we can say we gave them a choice. If things go bad after that, we can say we tried to do what was best, but they ultimately made the decision.  Maybe then we could at least be seen as the good guys, or at least less bad.

Yeah, I totally think gender discrimination is still a thing in the U.S. It's not just about women though. It's more about the specific field you're working in.  I mean, overall, women face tougher times because of that invisible "glass ceiling."  Even though equality is the goal, many people struggle to work for a woman in a leadership position, just because of how society's always been. So, often, women see a job they're qualified for, but the board might not promote them because traditionally, women haven't held top positions in business. And, I guess the same goes for men too.  

Think about things like being a stay-at-home parent. It's super uncommon for a man to stay home while his wife works. People often judge them, assuming the man should be the breadwinner. It can be tough for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be at home with their kids, even if their wife has the higher-paying job.  But society doesn't get it.

And then there's the fashion industry.  Men who are into fashion, especially straight men, sometimes don't get taken seriously. I don't know if that makes sense, but maybe it's because people think guys who are into fashion have different lifestyles. So, if a guy fits the typical mold and he's in fashion, people might wonder, "How can he really understand fashion if he's not more like us, the women?"

It's like, depending on your field, there's definitely gender discrimination in the U.S. Changing it is tough because society has a set way of thinking, even though we've come a long way since the 1800s. Change is slow, but women are rising in business, becoming CEOs and getting more acceptance.  It's happening, and people are starting to get on board.

The same goes for stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because people realize maybe the wife is the better earner, or maybe she just wants to work. And in fashion, maybe people are listening to their wives or female friends and understanding where men are coming from.

So, we have to promote these stereotypes by showing off the good qualities of those who are usually looked down on, but not in a pushy way. You can't force change, or people will resist. We're in a good spot where things are starting to change naturally.  

I don't think there's anything else we can do right now besides what's already being done. Change takes time, and we've already come a long way.  

Oh, and I think people discriminate against each other based on where they're from too. If a guy grew up on a farm and his grammar isn't perfect, but he's super smart and becomes a CEO, some men might make fun of him, saying things like, "How can I trust you if you don't even speak correctly?" You know?

So, they didn't exactly make marijuana legal, they decriminalized it.  

Think of it like this: instead of being a criminal offense, it's now more like a traffic ticket.  You get cited, but you don't get arrested, booked, or hauled into jail. 

There are still some downsides though.  Even with decriminalization, things like job interviews might still be affected.  Those big, scary consequences of a drug charge, they don't always disappear.

But, on the other hand, getting caught with marijuana used to cost taxpayers a ton of money.  Think about it: arresting people, holding them in jail, court appearances, public defenders, judges, prosecutors... it all adds up. 

Places that are struggling financially might be hesitant to decriminalize even if it saved them money. 

Some places, like Denver, are more open to the idea.  They might even use the money saved to fund things like education, social programs, and food assistance.  

It's important to remember that just because something is decriminalized doesn't mean it should be everywhere.  We need to be careful about how it's handled.

If marijuana were fully legalized, it could end up like cigarettes, sold in gas stations and smoked everywhere.  That could lead to more people smoking and driving, and it might just feel uncomfortable for a lot of people.

I think alcohol actually has a bigger impact on your ability to drive safely, but marijuana can be more disruptive to someone's everyday life.  

Ultimately, every substance affects people differently.  Some people can handle it better than others.  It's tough to generalize.

I'd say yes, because a lot of what they do is pretty traditional. They've done things the same way for ages, and it's good to have those roots. But it's also important to be able to change with the times, you know?  

A lot of Catholics think they have to go to church every week, and they're pretty strict about how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow every single rule perfectly.  They don't really accept people who aren't exactly "ideal" Catholics, and they don't accept people of other religions either.  Like, for example, my dad was an Episcopalian and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't let them get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion.

It doesn't seem very tolerant of other faiths to me. We were always taught to love everyone, which is a Catholic thing, but it feels hypocritical to say you love others and then not accept them the way they are.  So, a lot of Catholic teachings are about doing things a certain way, but then the way they actually practice goes against it because it's so stuck in the past.

I don't think allowing priests to get married would necessarily change things. I personally think it would be a good idea, but I don't think it would stop priests from abusing children. It's a whole different issue.  It might help a little, but I'm not sure.


I mean, people who hurt children probably would do it whether or not they were married. It's about a power imbalance, not about being married or not. If someone is going to abuse a child, they're going to do it whether they have a spouse or not. I don't think letting priests get married would stop that from happening.

I'm still figuring out my stance on this whole marriage equality debate. It's really tough, you know? It feels like it walks a fine line between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage actually means.  It's hard not to offend anyone when you're trying to define something so personal. 

I'm leaning towards the idea that all unions, whether they're between two men, two women, or a man and a woman, should be treated as civil unions.  After all, the government doesn't get involved in religious ceremonies like baptism, right?  Why should marriage be any different?  It's about two people coming together, and that's what matters.

I think it's important for the government to stay out of people's personal lives and not dictate who they can marry.  If all the states can agree on a reasonable solution, maybe they could push for it to become federal law.  

But a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? That seems extreme.  Changing the constitution shouldn't be taken lightly, especially for something like this. It's a big deal for some people, but I don't think it's important enough to warrant amending the constitution.

Growing up in a Christian household, my views on homosexuality are a bit complicated. I have lots of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I believe they should have the right to marry. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something decided by each individual state.

Think about it: some states are more liberal, while others are more conservative. Democratic states are more likely to support gay marriage, and people living there should be able to live in accordance with their state's values. If you choose to live in a state that legalizes it, you're essentially accepting that decision.

Basically, I think everyone, regardless of sexual orientation, deserves equal opportunities. So, I believe in leaving the decision of whether or not to legalize gay marriage up to each state. 

I don't think President Bush should have the power to ban it nationwide.  He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't be able to dictate how each state should govern itself. Plus, with a new president potentially coming in soon, it's likely to become a back-and-forth issue. It's best to let individual states make their own choices, as they're the ones who will ultimately live with the consequences.

Look, I get it. Myspace is like a public bulletin board, right? Whatever you post, anyone can see it. So if you're putting something on there, you kind of have to assume people are going to see it, even people like school officials. I mean, even if they weren't looking under the school's name, they could still find it from home. 

But when it comes to preventing something terrible like a school shooting, I think the school has a responsibility to keep everyone safe. If they see something online that makes them think a student might be a danger, I think it's okay for them to look into it. 

It's different if they're just snooping around looking for kids doing things they shouldn't, like drinking or smoking. That's an invasion of privacy. But if it's about protecting kids, I think it's fine. 

Think about it: you wouldn't want to send your kid to a school where the staff wasn't doing everything they could to keep them safe, right? 

It's just like with emails. You wouldn't want to put anything nasty about someone in an email because you never know who might see it later.  Everything online can come back to bite you. 

So, yeah, I think the school officials were justified in looking at the Myspace page. They were just trying to keep everyone safe.

Okay, so, about the war... at first, I was all for it because 9/11 hit me personally. I wanted revenge, you know? But looking back, I think we went in too emotionally.  We didn't really plan things out, and now I think it backfired.

I don't think being there is helping. It seems like they're just fighting amongst themselves anyway, and we're caught in the middle.  Honestly, because of 9/11, I've kind of checked out. I don't care what happens over there anymore.

It's frustrating. They're so different from us when it comes to war. It's savage. They don't want to make their country better; they just want us out. And maybe that's okay. Maybe we should just leave.

I think we were more angry than anything when we went in.  We wanted revenge, and I think President Bush let that dictate his actions.  But I get it, we couldn't just ignore what happened.

I just wish we had a better plan. We didn't know what we were walking into, and I don't think we had a clear goal. There wasn't any unity. 

We made some progress, but it's not enough.  We can't stay forever, and I honestly think things will just fall apart once we leave. We're hurting ourselves by staying there.
